None of us have it all figured out. I don‚Äôt care how smart you think you are or what position you hold -- listen to the wisdom of others. 

Be thankful that the worst-case scenario can be avoided by listening to someone wiser than you.

Then it came through from my Platoon Sergeant who had been in the lead vehicle -- no casualties. 

And second only to the birth of my children, it was the best feeling in the world.

That Lance Corporal is alive today because my Battalion Commander made a good decision.

And Second Lieutenant Auchincloss thought that he was wiser.

I think about that often. I try to embed that humility into how I approach questions big and small.

I may have thought we sacrificed training, but my Marines showed me otherwise.

I didn‚Äôt even have to give an order. They were sweeping. They were providing cover. They were evacuating the Marines.

And there were about 45 seconds of radio silence.

Immediately, I thought something wasn‚Äôt right. This is exactly what the Taliban wanted us to be doing. We needed to rethink this. 

BOOM! An IED struck our lead vehicle.

I‚Äôll never forget that feeling; I can see it in my consciousness now. I could picture the driver of the lead vehicle. Lance Corporal. 19 years old. It was like every drop of blood was out of my body.

23-year-old Second Lieutenant Auchincloss thought that this Lieutenant Colonel did not know what he was doing. I thought it was going to hinder our offensive capabilities and really undermine our training. 

I believed this decision was a mistake.

I commanded a forward patrol base. We were going out on daily patrols of Taliban-influenced villages. One day, there was a gunfight down at Helmand River and we were the closest platoon. 

I directed the platoon in single file down a narrow dirt road to the village.

Right before we left, our Battalion Commander made a decision that we were going to switch out the vehicles that we were using, from light armored vehicles to IED resistant vehicles.

This came at a cost. It hindered our mobility, maintenance, and firepower.

I graduated infantry in 2011 at 23 years old. Boy, was I confident. 

I knew the tactics. I did well in training. And upon deployment to Afghanistan, I thought I had it figured out.

On Veterans Day, I wanted to share a story with you about my own service. It‚Äôs a story of humility, and one of the most important lessons that I‚Äôve learned.

Options are a complicated investment tool. Yes, they are a fast way to make money. They are also a fast way to lose money. Industry regulators require brokerages to vet customers who want to trade options. Robinhood, by contrast, pushes options onto its users.

Gamifying day-trading, payment for order flow, and encouraging options trading prevent Robinhood from being a fiduciary to its customers, as required by Massachusetts law. Robinhood needs to make changes to protect its‚Äô customers best interests.

Due to the complexity of options trading, new or casual investors are destined to lose out to experienced options traders.
 
68% of MA customers approved for options trading on @RobinhoodApp had limited to no investment experience.

Payment for order flow is Robinhood‚Äôs primary source of revenue and the reason it can offer commission-free trading to customers.
 
Doesn‚Äôt payment for order flow incentivize Robinhood to encourage customers to trade as often as possible regardless of their trade quality?
